captions.text: We’ve been working on the building for quite some time now and it’s already very tall.
But when you take a step back and take a look, it really is very big.
What course will the Baron 1898 track take? Lots of people are curious to see what happens after the tunnel.
In this series of films we take you on a journey through the development and...
... creation of Efteling’s latest spectacular rollercoaster.
In this episode we join the project team on a working trip to Budapest.
In addition, one of the Baron 1898’s best kept secrets is revealed.
What course does the track of the new and spectacular dive coaster take?
This is ‘The Making of: Baron 1898’.
Contracted by rollercoaster manufacturer B&M, the construction of...
...Baron 1898 is taking place at various locations around the world.
The rails come from the US, while the unique lift tower is being manufactured in Hungary.
We are currently in Hungary at the steelworks in which the tower, the iconic element that most represents our attraction, is being made.
A large section of tower is here behind me, as you can see, ready for our inspection.
Once we have left, the tower will be taken apart and spray painted before being transported to the Netherlands.
If you look at other B&M dive coasters, you will notice that they all look quite similar.
During discussions with Efteling, B&M was so enthusiastic about...
...our design that they went along with it wholeheartedly.
They even went as far as to produce the Efteling arches for us.
This tower is unique throughout the whole world; it is truly Efteling.
The unique mineshaft tower will soon be fitted into place.
But what people would really like to know is what course the Baron 1898 track will take?
Lots of people are curious to see what happens after the tunnel.
When you exit the terminal building you experience a steep climb at a 45-degree angle, taking you to a height of almost 30 metres.
Once you are there you don’t immediately begin to descend.
You are held there for two seconds, which we call the ‘stop before you drop’.
At the end of the two seconds you are released and fall straight down the mineshaft.
After the tunnel there is an ‘Immelmann’ turn, which involves a half loop with a half roll.
If you survive this you move on to a 'Zero-G roll'.
This is an inside-out corkscrew, which causes momentary weightlessness.
This is followed by the 'Spiral'; a fast spiral descent, like the Python’s but much quicker.
When you shoot out of the spiral there is one final bend before the relief of re-entering the terminal building.
The ride lasts 130 seconds.
You descend at speeds of up to 90 km per hour, the quickest part of which is the fall into the mineshaft.
I have been fortunate enough to ride on many rollercoasters around the world.
The nicest thing about this ride is that it is not just a rollercoaster but more of an experience.
The combination of theming, design and thrilling ride makes it a...
...unique rollercoaster and one which could only be realised at Efteling.
We have been to Hungary, where we inspected the tower’s component sections.
These sections have been transported to Kaatsheuvel and are ready to be assembled on site.
We have made a start on the construction, which is standing here now.
You can see the attraction and the track starting to take shape.
The connection between the building and the track is becoming more apparent, which is wonderful to see.
The motor unit will soon arrive and still has to be installed within the building.
The building is already sealed but we have constructed a section of the roof in such a way that it can be easily removed.
If everything goes to plan, the motor unit should fit through precisely.
Once inside, the motor unit will be manoeuvred into position.
After the motor unit has been installed we will continue with the lift.
The lift components are already being brought inside.
We’ve made a kind of bench on which they can be stored.
The stairs will be fitted on the side.
We will assemble as many components as possible while they are still on the ground.
Once the lift has been assembled, it will be lifted into position.
As well as the mineshaft, further work will take place on the lift, which will form the connection between the building and the tower.
In addition, the heavy lift motor will be hoisted into the building through a special opening in the roof.
It won’t be long before the unique course of the Baron 1898’s...
...track will also be visible outside the building.
Subscribe and stay on the lookout for further episodes of 'The Making-of: Baron 1898'.
